summary: plants have been used by humans thousands of years ago as construction material [1], clothing [2], and obviously, as food and drugs [3] the use of plants themselves, their derived natural compounds and their biological and therapeutic properties have become a topic of increasing interest and investigation. antidiabetic, anti-inflammatory, anticonvulsant, analgesic, and cytotoxic activities are also cytotoxic. some of the most relevant studies on the bioactivities of Juniperus extracts show clearly that Juniperus continues to be a hot spot in research. n-hexane extract exhibits the broadest spectrum of activity with IC50 values of 10, 14, 16, and 40 g/mL against hepatocellular carcinoma cell line HepG2, human breast cancer cell line MCF-7, human lung carcinoma A549, and human bladder carcinoma cell line EJ138. ethanol extract showed the strongest cytotoxic activity (IC50 values of 0.06, 0.114, and 0.201 M on human colon cancer HCT116, human malignant melanoma the authors of this study suggest that -pinene would likely be the responsible for the J. oxycedrus essential oil antitrypanosomal properties. in another study using male mice, Juniperus virginiana L. essential oil at 400 and 800 mg/kg showed anxiolytic effect. Juniperus L. metabolites pharmaceutical potential has been well reviewed in 2006 [12] and in 2015 [13] this work aims to update the information relative to recent studies involving Juniperus species secondary metabolites. it is important to highlight that this is not an exhaustive review of all the studies regarding compounds with biological activities form Juniperus species. us species and its derivatives (1a and 1b) with significant cytotoxic and antibacterial activities. dehydroabietic acid derivatives possess a 1,2,3-triazole-tethered nucleus at C-14. the majority of the newly synthesized derivatives displayed effective antiproliferative activities. the results showed that these dehydroabietic acid derivatives showed great antibacterial effect with minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) values ranging from 0.39 to 0.78 g/mL against the same bacteria strain. the meta-CF3 phenyl derivative (1b) showed the highest antibacterial activity, similar to the positive-control compound vancomycin. ferruginol (2) downregulated the expression levels of anti-apoptotic protein Bcl-2 (related to mitochondrial apoptosis pathway) and upregulated pro-apoptotic proteins Bcl-2-associated X (Bax), caspase-3, and caspase-9. increased production, accumulation, and aggregation of the neurotoxic peptide amyloid- (A) within the brain triggers severe molecular changes affecting many signaling pathways associated ferruginol is the starting material for the synthesis of several compounds with high activity level and less secondary effects. the ferruginol derivative with a phthalimide moiety at C-18 (2a) was ten times better (EC50 = 1.4 M) than the reference ribavirin (EC50 = 13.5 M) against Dengue Virus type 2 in a post-infection treatment. Juniperus przewalskii Kom. and Juniperus squamata Buch.-Ham. ex D.Don have interest for the scientific community due to its pharmacological potential. hinokiol has been reported to inhibit the generation of nitric oxide (NO) and TNF-, as well as the production of pro-inflammatory enzymes from lipopolysaccharide-stimulated RAW macrophages. antioxidant [50] and hepato sugiol inhibits 28.2 to 67.4% of tyrosinase activity, only a little less active than kojic acid used as reference. sugiol inhibits 28.2 to 67.4% of tyrosinase activity. giol may be useful against human solid tumors as an inhibitor of transketolase (TKT) and of the signal transducer and activator of transcription 3 (STAT3). inhibition interrupts the production of FAD, NAD(P)+, CoA, and ATP. STAT3 inhibition plays an important role in the induction of cancer cells apoptosis. sugiol is a very good candidate to in vivo evaluation against pancreatic cancer. authors of this study have not evaluated the compounds cytotoxicity towards a non-tumor cell line under the same conditions. if they had, they would have increased the impact of their work and its contribution to the field. totarol (5) is no toxicity on cerebellar granule cells (CGC) at various concentrations (1 to 5 M), which strengthens its protective properties. in vitro assay showed totarol as no toxicity on cerebellar granule cells. bioactive flavonoids amentoflavone (6) and rutin (7) from Juniperus species. amentoflavone (6) possesses a wide variety of bioactivities, such as antiphotoaging [75], antifungal [76], antimicrobial [77], antioxidant [78], anti-inflammatory [79], antipsoriasis [81], diuretic [82], antitumor [83,84], and neuroprotective [85] and osteogenesis effects amentoflavone (6) could act as an aromatase inhibitor. treatment with 20 mg/kg and 40 mg/kg doses of amentoflavone (6) has suitable anti-arthritic properties. another study examined the effects of amentoflavone in human ovarian cancer cell lines. the amentoflavone (6) inhibitory activity on human aldo-keto reductase family 1 member B10 (AKR1B10) was studied. compound (6) decrease the growth of human lung cancer cells in vitro and in vivo by potently inhibition of human AKR1B10 activity. cetin 3-rutinoside (7) is a flavonol found in many plants including Juniperus species like J. communis, J. excelsa, J. foetidissima, and J. oxycedrus. it possesses multiple pharmacological activities, including antioxidant, hepatoprotective, vasoprotective, anticarcinogenic, neuroprotective, cardioprotective and antidiabetic activities. stressed animals treated with rutin (7) presented an intact hippocampus with morphology and cell number similar to control animals that were not subjected to CUS. stressed animals treated with rutin carcinoma HT-29, breast carcinoma MDA-MB-231 and human choriocarcinoma JeG-23. etoposide was less efficient (IC50 73.57 nM). deoxypodophyllotoxin (8) suppressed in vivo the tumor growth in MCF-7/S and in MCF-7/A xenograft mice. in addition, DPT (8) has potential to be a new microtubule inhibitor for breast cancer treatment since its antitubulin polymerization activity showed the absence of polymerized tubulin. cytotoxic effect of DPT (8) on human prostate cancer DU-145 cells. apoptosis was also induced through downregulation of levels of phosphorylated Akt and activation of the p53/B-cell lymphoma 2 associated X protein/phosphatase and tensin homolog (i.e., Akt/p53/Bax/PTEN) signaling pathway. alterations of parthanatos-related proteins triggered by DPT (8) occurred in a defend that this PBPK-PD model could be used with other compounds besides DPT. the same deoxypodophyllotoxin derivative (8a) can cause cell-cycle arrest in the G2/M phase by affecting levels of the cell-cycle regulators p-cdc2, cdc2 and cyclin B1 [128] same derivative (8a) at concentrations of 0.1 and 0.3 M, showed better antiproliferative activity than etoposide at 1 M, and low cytotoxicity against human normal lung cells WI-38. dehydroabietic acid (1) has a lipophilic abietan-8,11,13-trien structure with only one polar substituent, the equatorial carboxylic group at C-4. this acid is widely distributed in nature, being present in J. oxycedrus, J. phoenicea, and Juniperus brevifolia. dehydroabietic acid derivatives showed great antibacterial effect with minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) values ranging from 0.78 to 1.56 g/mL against the strains tested. the meta-CF3 phenyl derivative (1b) showed the highest antibacterial activity against the same bacteria strain. ferruginol (2) has antitumor activity, presenting inhibitory effects on HepG2 and Hep3B cell lines without affecting normal hepatocyte line L-02 viability. ferruginol (2) downregulated expression levels of anti-apoptotic protein Bcl-2 (related to mitochondrial apoptosis pathway) increased production, accumulation, and aggregation of the neurotoxic peptide amyloid- (A) within the brain triggers severe molecular changes affecting many signaling pathways associated with neuronal metabolism, signaling, and neuronal communication. ferruginol (2) may have a potential neuroprotective role in neurodegenerative alterations. Hinokiol Hinokiol is a 3,12-dihydroxy-abieta-8,11,13-trien present in Juniperus species, e.g., J. brevifolia, J. chinensis, J. excelsa, J. phoenicea, Juniperus procera Hochst. ex Endl. Juniperus przewalskii Kom. and Juniperus squamata Buch.-Ham. VGSCs are crucial in excitability of neurons because they permit the influx of Na+ during the upstroke phase of action potential. the VGSC inhibition by hinokiol presented in this work could be interpreted as an anti-anxiety, anaesthetic or anticonvulsant activity. further research is necessary to clarify this topic and hypothesize about future pharmacological applications. sugiol inhibits 28.2 to 67.4% of tyrosinase activity. at concentration 0.020 to 0.50 mg/mL, sugiol inhibits only a little less active than kojic acid used as reference. cytotoxic activity of sugiol was found to be caused by reactive oxygen species (ROS)-mediated alterations in mitochondrial membrane potential (MMP) also caused cell cycle arrest in G2/M phase of the cell cycle, ultimately leading to apoptosis. authors of this study have not evaluated the compounds cytotoxicity towards a non-tumor cell line under the same conditions. drupaceae Labill is the most abundant compound in the hexane extract of J. brevifolia bark [54], being also found in species from other genus [63]. totarol (5) has vascular protective effects in vivo, by activating the protein kinase B/heme oxygenase-1 (PKB/HO-1) pathway. a post-ischemia administration of totarol in rats (1 and 10 g/kg) was used. the results showed considerable decreases in infarct volume compared with the untreated group. the study also reported notably infarct volume reduction with 10 g/kg of totarol administration. the dehydroabietic acid methyl ester derivative (1a) was the most potent derivative tested. it showed better IC50 values against the tested cells lines (PC-3, SK-OV-3, MDA-MB-231 and MCF-7 human cell lines) than fluorouracil (5-Fu) the meta-CF3 phenyl derivative (1b) showed the highest antibacterial activity, similar to the positive-control compound vancomycin. it is widely distributed in Juniperus genus [13,35], being particularly abundant in hexane extract of J. excelsa berries. ferruginol (2) downregulated the expression levels of anti-apoptotic protein Bcl-2 (related to mitochondrial apoptosis pathway) and upregulated pro-apoptotic proteins Bcl-2-associated X (Bax), caspase-3, and caspase-9. increased production, accumulation, and aggregation of the neurotoxic peptide amyloid- (A) within the brain triggers severe molecular changes. ferruginol (2) is the starting material for the synthesis of several compounds with high activity level and less secondary effects. the ferruginol derivative with a phthalimide moiety at C-18 (2a) was ten times better (EC50 = 1.4 M) than the reference ribavirin against Dengue Virus type 2 in a post-infection treatment. antioxidant [50] and hepatoprotective [51] effects have also been reported for hinokiol. antitumor properties against human ovarian carcinoma (HO-8910) and cervical carcinoma (HeLa) cell lines have also been reported. sugiol inhibits tyrosinase and -glucosidase activity in vitro. sugiol inhibits 28.2 to 67.4% of tyrosinase activity, only a little less active than kojic acid used as reference. STAT3 activation was 40% inhibited by 20 M of sugiol in DU145 prostate cancer cells. inhibition of TKT by sugiol imply ROS-mediated ERK activation. ERK activated phosphorylates STAT3 on Ser727 and recruits a protein tyrosine phosphatase MEG2 leading to the inhibition of STAT3 [59] totarol (5) is a tricyclic phenolic diterpene with a totarane skeleton. it is the most abundant compound in the hexane extract of J. brevifolia bark. a promising antimicrobial target is the bacterial cell division machinery and totarol (5) has the capacity to restrain bacterial growth. in vitro assay showed totarol as no toxicity on cerebellar granule cells (CGC) at various concentrations (1 to 5 M), which strengthens its protective properties. totarol treatment (1 and 10 g/kg) radically enhanced the ischemia-induced neurological deficit. bioactive flavonoids amentoflavone (6) and rutin (7) from Juniperus species are well reviewed with great detail. amentoflavone (6) possesses a wide variety of bioactivities, such as antiphotoaging [75], antifungal [76], antimicrobial [77], antioxidant [78], anti-inflammatory [79], antipsoriasis [81], diuretic [82] and antitumor [83,84], and it confers treatment with 20 mg/kg and 40 mg/kg doses of amentoflavone (6) has suitable anti-arthritic properties. amentoflavone (6) protected dopaminergic neurons against MPTP/MPP+-induced neurotoxicity. compound (6) decreases growth of human AKR1B10 cells in vitro and in vivo by potently inhibition of human AKR1B10 activity. amentoflavone (6) could trigger Nrf2 activation through ROS-mediated activation of the p38-AKT/PKB pathway in HaCaT keratinocytes. rutin at 50 M was more effective than the cardioprotective agent dexrazoxane (DZR) at same concentration, in preventing pirarubicin-induced toxicity in rat cardiomyoblasts. the apoptosis rate of rutin (7) treatment after cells exposed to pirarubicin was nearly 20%, while DZR treatment reported an apoptosis rate of about 30%. vone Amentoflavone (6) is a flavonoid dimer composed by two apigenin units linked by a carbon-carbon bond between C-8 and C-3′. amentoflavone (6) possesses a wide variety of bioactivities, such as antiphotoaging [75], antifungal [76], antimicrobial [77], antioxidant [78], anti-inflammatory [79], antidiabetic [80], antipsoriasis [81], di amentoflavone (6) can be used to develop safe and high-efficacy hair loss treatment. aromatase catalyses the rate-limiting step in endogen/estrogen synthesis. it could act as an aromatase inhibitor being determined the IC50 value as 93.6 M. apoptotic cell population increased after 48 h and 72 h treatment at 20 M and 50 M. amentoflavone (6) repressed expression of kinase protein 2 (Skp2) through ROS/AMPK/mTOR signaling. amentoflavone (6), with an IC50 value of 3.9 0.5 M, was recognized as a potential DPP-IV inhibitor. the flavonol is found in many plants including Juniperus species like J. communis, J. excelsa, J. foetidissima, and J. oxycedrus. rutin (7) (100 mg/kg) could alleviate chronic unpredictable stress (CUS) in mice, acting as an antidepressant. stressed animals treated with rutin (7) presented an intact hippocampus with morphology and cell number similar to control animals. deoxypodophyllotoxin (8) has a significant cytotoxic activity in vitro. it has inhibited the growth of numerous cancer cell lines. the same study also suggests that deoxypodophyllotoxin (8) induced apoptosis via caspase-dependent pathways. /A cell lines with IC50 values of 10.61 1.09 nM and 5.86 0.30 nM respectively. resistance index (RI) was better than those obtained by paclitaxel and etoposide. also suppressed in vivo the tumor growth in MCF-7/S and in MCF-7/A xenograft mice. the results revealed that DPT (8) induced cell apoptosis and inhibited cell proliferation. apoptosis was also induced through downregulation of the levels of phosphorylated Akt and activation of the p53/B-cell lymphoma 2 associated X protein/phosphatase and tensin homolog. alterations of parthanatos-related proteins triggered by DPT (8) occurred in a dose and time dependent manner. deoxypodophyllotoxin (8) induces both autophagy and apoptosis in osteosarcoma u2OS cells. the PBPK-PD model predicts antitumor effectiveness in tumor-bearing mice. the PBPK-PD model uses in vitro/in vivo pharmacodynamic correlations. the authors defend that this PBPK-PD model could be used with other compounds besides DPT. pG2 cells are less toxic (IC50 = 113.8 M) to WI-38 cells than 5-FU and etoposide (IC50 values cytotoxic derivatives (8a) and (8b) ovarian carcinoma HO-8910, ovarian carcinoma SK-0V-3, human colon carcinoma HT-29, breast carcinoma MDA-MB-231 and human choriocarcinoma JeG-23. etoposide was less deoxypodophyllotoxin (8) appears to be the most promising one in terms of development into a pharmaceutical natural drug. the dehydroabietic acid derivative 1a also appears to be a good bet for further studies and development. the majority of the studies addressed in this review were made at the in vitro scale. the more active and promising compounds presented in Juniperus species should be taken to the next step. studies regarding any bioactivity assay should always present IC50 values of a reference compound in order to increase their scientific impact and facilitate results comparison.
